questions.text: An AIDS-positive patient came with a history of fever, vomiting, and meningismus. Which of the following tests help in the rapid diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis?

choices.text: Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

Explanation:

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen is a rapid, highly sensitive, and specific for cryptococcal antigen detection. It can detect antigen even before symptoms develop in AIDS patients. It is the best for rapid bedside diagnosis in resource-limited settings.

Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system

  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections

 

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen- Best rapid diagnostic test.

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

India Ink Preparation of CSF (Option A):

  • Detects the capsulated yeast Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF.
  • Useful but low sensitivity, especially in cases with low fungal burden.

Blood Culture (Option B):

  • Can grow Cryptococcus in disseminated cases but takes several days.
  • Not a rapid diagnostic method.

CSF Culture (Option C):

  • Gold standard but time-consuming (takes 3-7 days).
  • Requires Sabouraud dextrose agar for fungal growth.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

Phialophora Verrucosa (Option D) is a dematiaceous fungus associated with chromoblastomycosis, a chronic subcutaneous fungal infection characterized by slowly developing granulomatous lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the probable cause in a case of tinea capitis where white powdery colonies were obtained from the hair specimen and the hair perforation test was positive on the isolate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

Explanation:

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp, commonly caused by dermatophytes. In this case, the white powdery colonies observed from the hair specimen and the positive hair perforation test are key diagnostic clues.
  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes is a common cause of tinea capitis, and it is known for producing white, powdery colonies on culture media. The hair perforation test is used to differentiate dermatophytes, and a positive result indicates that the organism can break down the hair shaft, a characteristic feature of Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes is also capable of infecting both the hair and skin, and its positive perforation test helps distinguish it from other dermatophytes.

Hair Perforation Test

  • Purpose: Differentiate between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Procedure

  1. Place strands of human hair in a petri dish with 20 ml of distilled water.
  2. Autoclave the dish.
  3. Add sterile 10% yeast extract and fragments of the test fungus to the hair.
  4. Incubate at 25°C for 2-3 weeks.
  5. Examine the hair microscopically with a lactophenol cotton blue-stained wet preparation.

Test Results

  • Positive- If T. mentagrophytes is present:
    • The hair shaft appears wedge-shaped due to surface erosion. (Option C)
  • Negative- T. rubrum (Option A ruled out)

Characteristics of Fungal Infections:

  • Both T. rubrum and T. mentagrophytes cause ectothrix hair infections, where arthrospores form a sheath around the hair.
  • T. rubrum is the most common dermatophyte in humans, often leading to chronic, treatment-resistant lesions.

Identification Methods

Method

Description

Macroscopic examination

Assess the growth rate, texture, and colour on media

Urea hydrolysis test

Determines ability to hydrolyze urea

Growth on polished rice or special media

Tests the ability to grow in specific conditions

Temperature tolerance test

Assesses resistance to elevated temperatures

Nutritional requirements test

Checks requirements for specific amino acids and vitamins

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Trichophyton rubrum (Option A): This species is typically associated with tinea corporis (ringworm), tinea pedis (athlete’s foot), and onychomycosis (nail infection). It produces red to yellowish colonies and does not typically give a positive hair perforation test, making it less likely to be the cause of tinea capitis in this case.

Trichophyton schoenleinii (Option B): This organism is a rare cause of tinea capitis, especially in children, and is known for producing scaly, grayish-white colonies. It typically produces a negative hair perforation test, so it is unlikely in this case.

Trichophyton violaceum (Option D): This species is associated with tinea capitis, but it usually forms purple or violet-colored colonies rather than white powdery colonies. Moreover, it does not typically show a positive hair perforation test, making it less likely as the causative agent in this case.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago presents with diarrhea for 9 days. A stool sample subjected to Kinyoun stain reveals 4-6 μm structures. Which of the following is true about the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sporozoites adhere to intestinal mucosa

Explanation:

  • The organism described is Cryptosporidium, which exhibits autoinfection due to thin-walled oocysts that do not exit the host and instead continue the infection cycle, contributing to chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. (Option A ruled out)
  • After ingestion, the sporozoites excyst from oocysts in the small intestine and attach to the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to malabsorption, secretory diarrhea, and epithelial damage.

Life Cycle of Cryptosporidium

1. Ingestion of Infective Oocysts: Humans or animals ingest fully mature (sporulated) oocysts from contaminated water, food, or surfaces.

2. Excystation: In the host’s small intestine, the oocyst releases four sporozoites, which then attach to the intestinal epithelial cells.

3. Trophozoite Formation: The sporozoites develop into trophozoites within parasitophorous vacuoles (specialised compartments) in the brush border of the host’s intestinal cells.

4. Asexual Reproduction (Schizogony): Trophozoites undergo asexual reproduction to form type I meronts, each containing eight merozoites.

5. Release of Merozoites: The merozoites are released, infect new epithelial cells, and may undergo schizogony again to form more type I meronts or transition into type II meronts.

6. Sexual Reproduction (Gametogony): Type II meronts release merozoites that invade cells and begin the sexual phase, differentiating into microgametes (male) and macrogametes (female).

7. Fertilization and Oocyst Formation: The microgamete fertilises the macrogamete, forming a zygote that then develops into an oocyst.

8. Sporulation: The zygote undergoes sporogony to form a fully mature, sporulated oocyst containing four sporozoites.

9. Release of Oocysts: Two types of oocysts are produced:

  • Thick-walled oocysts: Excreted in faeces, they are mature and infective and transmit the infection to new hosts.
  • Thin-walled oocysts: Remain in the intestine and cause autoinfection, maintaining the cycle within the same host.

10. Transmission: Thick-walled oocysts are released into the environment through faeces, where they can infect new hosts upon ingestion.

Both sexual and asexual reproduction occurs within one host

Sporozoites are the infective form (Option B): The oocyst is the infective form of Cryptosporidium, not the sporozoite. The oocyst releases four sporozoites, which invade intestinal epithelial cells.

High infectivity dose is required (Option D): Cryptosporidium has a low infectious dose; as few as 10-30 oocysts can cause infection, making it highly transmissible.

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in:


	Invasive aspergillosis
	Systemic candidiasis
	Mucormycosis
	Histoplasma capsulatm
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1 only

Explanation:

Galactomannan is primarily associated with Aspergillus infections, particularly invasive aspergillosis.

  • Galactomannan is a component of the Aspergillus cell wall
  • Detection of Galactomannan in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is a marker for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children, in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients or in patients with hematologic malignancies.

Galactomannan Test:

  • Detects galactomannan, a carbohydrate antigen specific to Aspergillus species.
  • Positive for: Aspergillus species
  • False-negative for: Most fungi except Aspergillus; not reliable for Candida, Pneumocystis jirovecii, or Mucorales.
  • Various fungi can generate galactomannan and cross-reactivity may happen, as seen with Histoplasma capsulatum, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, and Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Invasive Aspergillosis (Statement 1): Galactomannan is a polysaccharide component of the Aspergillus cell wall and is released into the bloodstream during invasive infection. Serum galactomannan antigen testing is used for early diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients (e.g., neutropenia, hematologic malignancies, transplant recipients).

Systemic Candidiasis (Statement 2): Candida species do not produce galactomannan. Instead, (1→3)-β-D-glucan is detected in the serum for invasive candidiasis.

Mucormycosis (Statement 3): Mucorales fungi (Rhizopus, Mucor, etc.) lack galactomannan in their cell wall. Diagnosis relies on histopathology and PCR rather than antigen tests.


Histoplasma capsulatum (Statement 4): It can be detected in urine and serum but is distinct from Aspergillus galactomannan.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Voriconazole

Explanation:

  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) occurs in immunocompromised patients (e.g., neutropenia, organ transplantation, prolonged corticosteroid use).
  • Voriconazole is the first-line drug

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA)

It is a hypersensitivity reaction to germinating fungal spores in the airway, primarily affecting individuals with asthma and cystic fibrosis (CF).

  • Symptoms:
    • Patients typically experience bronchial obstruction due to mucus plugs, leading to coughing fits, pneumonia-like symptoms, consolidation, and breathlessness.
    • Expectorating thick, often brown sputum casts.
    • Fever and breathlessness.
    • Worsening asthma symptoms.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serological Tests: Diagnosis of ABPA is made through:
  • Elevated specific and total serum IgE levels (>1000 IU/mL)

+

  • Positive skin-prick test
  • Imaging:
    • Presence of hyper-attenuated mucus in airways is highly specific
    • PROXIMAL/CENTRAL Bronchiectasis is characteristic
    • It may mimic pneumonia due to infiltrates
    • Segmental or lobar collapse on chest X-rays, especially in stable asthma cases
    • Tram track appearance in CT d/t bronchiectasis
    • X-ray:
      • Cylindrical & proximal bronchiectasis with thickening of the bronchial wall (Tree in bud appearance)
      • Mucous impaction in dilated bronchi (Finger-in-glove appearance)
  • HRCT: Central bronchiectasis and bronchial wall thickening with atelectatic areas.

Key features:

  • Presence of a History of Asthma (most common) episodes or Cystic fibrosis.
  • Proximal bronchiectasis (inner two-thirds of the chest CT field)
  • Positive skin test for Aspergillus fumigatus extract
  • Elevated total serum IgE levels (usually >1000 IU/mL)
  • Elevated Aspergillus fumigatus-specific IgE or IgG
  • Peripheral blood eosinophilia (> 0.5 × 10^9/L)
  • History or evidence of chest X-ray abnormalities.
  • Identification of fungal hyphae of Aspergillus fumigatus in sputum microscopy


Management of Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA):

  • Primary treatment: Itraconazole (Long-term therapy is often beneficial).
  • Low-Dose Oral Glucocorticoids: Prednisolone (7.5–10 mg daily) is generally recommended to suppress immunopathological responses and prevent progressive tissue damage.
  • Steroid-dependent cases: Itraconazole (400 mg/day) for 16 weeks
  • Management of exacerbations: Prednisolone (40–60 mg daily)
  • Invasive disease:
    • Primary treatment: Voriconazole, Isavuconazole, Posaconazole.
    • Monitor for drug interactions, especially with rifampin and carbamazepine.
  • Chronic pulmonary disease: Primary treatment is Voriconazole and Itraconazole.
  • Persistent symptoms: Bronchoscopy should be performed to remove impacted mucus and facilitate prompt lung re-inflation.
  • Surgical interventions: Necessary for certain cases, such as:
    • Fungal sinus balls
    • Single aspergillomas
    • Invasive forms affecting the heart, lungs, or brain
  • Prophylaxis:
    • High-Risk Situations: Antifungal prophylaxis for patients at moderate or high risk, particularly post-induction therapy for acute myeloid leukaemia
    • Common agents: Itraconazole and posaconazole (more effective in reducing infection rates).

Itraconazole (Option A): Used for chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), but not first-line for invasive disease.

Lyophilized Amphotericin B (Option C): Used as second-line therapy if voriconazole is contraindicated.

Posaconazole (Option D): Used for prophylaxis in high-risk immunocompromised patients (e.g., leukemia, bone marrow transplant)

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Oral Candidiasis

Explanation:

  • Oral candidiasis (thrush) is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive patients, caused by Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans.
  • Clinical Features:
    • White, curd-like plaques on the tongue, buccal mucosa, and palate
    • Easily scraped off, leaving erythematous mucosa underneath
  • Microscopy Findings:
    • Budding yeasts and pseudohyphae, seen on potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount or Gram stain
  • Strongly associated with immunosuppression, particularly CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm³ in HIV patients.

Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Lead to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment

Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.

C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

 

Hairy leukoplakia (Option B): Caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) in HIV patients.

  • It presents as white, corrugated plaques on the lateral tongue, which cannot be scraped off.
  • No budding yeasts or pseudohyphae seen on microscopy.

Lichen planus (Option C): Autoimmune condition with reticular white striations (Wickham’s striae) on buccal mucosa. Does not show budding yeasts or pseudohyphae on microscopy.

Diphtheria (Option D): Caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, presenting with grayish pseudomembranes in the oropharynx. Pseudomembranes are firmly adherent and bleed on removal, unlike the easily scraped plaques in oral candidiasis.

questions.text: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of burning sensation on eating hot or spicy food, and the following findings are seen. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candidiasis

Explanation:

Chronic use of inhaled steroids is a common risk factor for oral candidiasis (thrush), as steroids can suppress the immune system locally in the mouth, allowing Candida albicans to overgrow. This can lead to symptoms like a burning sensation, particularly when eating hot or spicy food, which can irritate the affected areas. Candidiasis in the mouth typically presents as white patches that can be scraped off, leaving a red, inflamed area underneath.

Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Lead to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.
  • C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

Burning Mouth Syndrome (Option B): This is a condition characterized by a burning or tingling sensation in the mouth, but it doesn't usually have associated lesions or plaques, and it’s not commonly linked to inhaled steroids or the presence of oral candidiasis.

Geographical Tongue (Option C): This condition involves a map-like appearance of the tongue with irregular, red, smooth areas surrounded by white borders. It usually doesn’t cause the same burning sensation with spicy food and isn’t typically associated with inhaled steroid use.


Oral Lichen Planus (Option D): This is an autoimmune condition that affects the mucous membranes of the mouth. It may cause burning or pain, but it typically presents with white, lacy lesions (Wickham’s striae) or erosive areas, which aren't characteristic of candidiasis.

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Cryptococcus

Explanation:

  • The India ink stain (A type of negative stain) is specifically used to visualize the capsule surrounding Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF samples.

  • A clear halo around the yeast cells indicates the presence of the capsule, which is an important virulence factor.

  • Urease test positive

  • Maltese cross appearance under polarising microscope

Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis .

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors

  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.

  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.

  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:

    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.

    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

 

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells

  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture

  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.

  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.

  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine

  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.

  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.

  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Ohio presents to a physician with a chronic cough. A chest x-ray demonstrates a cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the lymph node and staining with lactophenol cotton blue demonstrates the following characteristics as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Histoplasmosis:

Explanation:

  • Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It is commonly found in regions with soil that is enriched with bird or bat droppings, such as the Ohio River Valley. This makes the farmer from Ohio particularly at risk, as he may have been exposed to the fungus while working in environments with high concentrations of bird or bat feces.
  • The key features of histoplasmosis on the chest x-ray (cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy) are consistent with this diagnosis, as the infection often affects the lungs and can lead to chronic pulmonary disease in immunocompetent individuals. In some cases, it may cause granulomatous lymphadenopathy.
  • The appearance of Histoplasma on lactophenol cotton blue staining typically shows small, round, or oval yeast cells inside macrophages, which is characteristic of this fungal pathogen.
  • Based on the patient’s history, histopathology showing intramacrophagic yeast form and (LPCB) mount showing numerous hyaline hyphae with few tuberculate macroconidia (arrows) and many smooth-walled oval microconidia are pointing towards a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum, are helpful for immunocompromised individuals

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole

Incorrect Options:

Coccidioidomycosis (Option B): Caused by Coccidioides species, this fungal infection is more common in the southwestern United States (California, Arizona, New Mexico) and is characterized by arthroconidia (spores) in sputum or biopsy, not the intracellular yeast forms typical of histoplasmosis.

Cryptococcus (Option C): Cryptococcus neoformans is another fungal pathogen, but it typically presents with meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients. It does not usually cause cavitary lung lesions with hilar lymphadenopathy in the manner seen in histoplasmosis.

Blastomycosis (Option D): Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, blastomycosis can also cause pulmonary infection with cavitary lesions, but it typically presents with a larger yeast form in tissue, and is more common in areas around the Great Lakes, Mississippi River, and St. Lawrence River regions, rather than Ohio.

questions.text: In patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, which type of fungus is frequently linked to orbital cellulitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rhizopus:

  • Rhizopus is a genus of fungi, and the species most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis is Rhizopus.
  • This fungal infection is known as rhinocerebral mucormycosis.
  • Rhizopus can invade the sinuses and orbit, leading to orbital cellulitis. This infection can spread rapidly and is considered a medical emergency.
  • Predisposing factors for mucormycosis: Iron is essential for mucormycosis growth. High iron levels increase the risk of invasive mucormycosis.
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most important risk factor. Acidosis causes the release of iron from the sequestered proteins in the serum.
    • End-stage renal disease.
    • Patients taking iron therapy or deferoxamine (iron chelator)
    • Defects in phagocytic functions (e.g., neutropenia or steroid therapy).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candida: Candida is a genus of yeast that can cause oral thrush, vulvovaginitis, esophagitis, endocarditis, and UTI in individuals with weakened immune systems (HIV)

Option C - Aspergillus: Aspergillus is a genus of filamentous fungi commonly found in the environment. It can cause invasive fungal infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it is more commonly associated with lung infections such as invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.

Option D - Trichophyton: Trichophyton is a genus of fungi that primarily causes infections of the skin, hair, and nails. It is not commonly associated with orbital cellulitis or invasive fungal infections in the orbit in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: Which opportunistic pathogen demonstrates a “crushed ping pong ball appearance” on Gomori methenamine stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

Explanation:

The opportunistic pathogen demonstrating a “crushed ping pong ball appearance” on Gomori methenamine stain is Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

 
  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
 
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option A):

  • Appearance: Tiny intracellular yeast (2–5 μm) within macrophages.
  • Stains: Best seen with Giemsa or PAS, also silver stains, but they appear as small oval bodies, not crushed ping pong balls.
  • Clues in history: Associated with bird/bat droppings (caves, chicken coops), the Mississippi & Ohio River valleys.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option B):

  • Appearance: Round to oval yeast with a thick polysaccharide capsule.
  • Stains:
    • India ink - capsule appears as a clear halo.
    • Mucicarmine - capsule stains red.
  • Key feature: “Soap-bubble” lesions in the brain on MRI (cryptococcal meningitis).

Aspergillus fumigatus (Option D):

  • Appearance: Septate hyphae with acute-angle branching (~45°).
  • Stains: Silver stain highlights hyphae, but you see filamentous branching structures, not rounded cysts.
  • Clues: Causes allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergillomas (fungal balls), and invasive aspergillosis in neutropenic patients.

choices.text: Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

Explanation:

  • Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen is a rapid, highly sensitive, and specific for cryptococcal antigen detection. It can detect antigen even before symptoms develop in AIDS patients. It is the best for rapid bedside diagnosis in resource-limited settings.

Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system

    • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection
    • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
    • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
    • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections

Microscopy

    • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
    • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
    • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
    • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
    • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen- Best rapid diagnostic test.

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

 

India Ink Preparation of CSF (Option A):

  • Detects the capsulated yeast Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF.
  • Useful but low sensitivity, especially in cases with low fungal burden.

Blood Culture (Option B):

  • Can grow Cryptococcus in disseminated cases but takes several days.
  • Not a rapid diagnostic method.

CSF Culture (Option C):

  • Gold standard but time-consuming (takes 3-7 days).
  • Requires Sabouraud dextrose agar for fungal growth.

questions.text: A male patient presents with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid examination shows septate hyphae with acute angle (dichotomous) branching under microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Aspergillosis

Explanation:

  • Aspergillus species (most commonly A. fumigatus) produce thin, septate hyphae with acute angle branching (~45°), a hallmark microscopic finding.
  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis occurs primarily in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., neutropenia, post-transplant, prolonged corticosteroid use).
  • Clinically, it presents with fever, cough, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis due to vascular invasion.
  • BAL cytology and special stains (Gomori methenamine silver, PAS) confirm diagnosis.

Mucormycosis (Option A) shows broad, nonseptate hyphae with obtuse branching and tends to invade blood vessels aggressively.

Histoplasmosis (Option B) is a dimorphic fungus existing mostly as intracellular yeast in human tissue, thus hyphae are not observed in BAL fluid .

Candidiasis (Option D) usually involves budding yeast and pseudohyphae rather than true septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

Madurella mycetomatis is a common fungal agent associated with eumycetoma and is characterized by the presence of thick-walled grains and hyphae in microscopic examination.

Mycetoma (Madura Foot)

  • Definition: Chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous masses, draining sinuses, and grains in exudates
  • Types:

    • Actinomycetoma (bacterial)

  • Opportunistic Pathogen:
    • Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS patients with CD4+ counts <200 cells/mm³).
  • Colonization in Healthy Individuals:
    • Common in healthy lungs; most children are exposed by age 4.
    • Reactivation in adults is possible from childhood exposure or new infections.
  • Airborne Transmission:
    • Spreads through person-to-person contact, especially in hospital settings.
    • Colonized individuals exhale the organism, contaminating the environment.
  • Reinfection vs. Reactivation:
    • Both reinfection with new strains and reactivation of dormant infection are possible causes of recurrent PCP.
  • Environmental Reservoir:
    • Exact environmental source unknown, but the organism has been found in air samples near infected patients.

Clinical Features

  • General Symptoms
    • Fever
    • Nonproductive cough
    • Dyspnea (shortness of breath)
    • Tachypnea (rapid breathing)
  • Symptom Variations by Immune Status

  • In HIV-positive patients, particularly those with a weakened immune system (low CD4 count), Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of bilateral infiltrates in the lungs, leading to Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP).   • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a skin infection characterized by itching, redness, and scaling. Microscopic examination of a skin sample reveals a pencil-shaped appearance. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism responsible for this skin infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trichophyton

  • Trichophyton species are dermatophytic fungi that commonly cause fungal skin infections known as dermatophytoses or ringworm. These infections are characterized by itching, redness, and scaling of the skin. The term "pencil-shaped appearance" refers to the appearance of the fungal hyphae under the microscope, where the hyphae have a tapered, narrow appearance resembling a pencil. Trichophyton species can cause various types of dermatophytoses, including tinea corporis (ringworm of the body), tinea cruris (jock itch), tinea pedis (athlete's foot), and others.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Microsporum: Microsporum species are another group of dermatophytic fungi that can cause fungal skin infections. They also lead to symptoms like itching, redness, and scaling. However, unlike the "pencil-shaped appearance" mentioned in the question, Microsporum species are known for their characteristic appearance under the microscope, where they produce large, multicellular, club-shaped structures called macroconidia. Therefore, this is not the correct answer in this case.

Option C - Epidermophyton: Epidermophyton species are also dermatophytic fungi responsible for causing fungal skin infections. They can cause similar symptoms as described in the question, but the "pencil-shaped appearance" is not typically associated with Epidermophyton species. Instead, they produce smooth, thin-walled, and irregularly branched hyphae. Therefore, this is not the correct answer in this case.

Option D - None of the above: This option is not the correct answer because the presentation of itching, redness, scaling, and the specific "pencil-shaped appearance" of hyphae in the skin sample is indicative of a dermatophytic fungal infection, and the most likely causative organism among the given options is Trichophyton.

questions.text: A man has undergone a renal transplant and is taking immunosuppressant drugs. On biopsy, gram positive budding cells with pseudohyphae are observed. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candida

Explanation:

  • The presence of budding cells with pseudohyphae on biopsy strongly suggests Candida infection.
  • Candida species are opportunistic pathogens in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., transplant recipients).
  • Candida exists in different morphological forms:
    • Budding yeast (blastoconidia)
    • Pseudohyphae (elongated yeast cells with constrictions at septa, forming chains)
    • True hyphae (seen in invasive disease, germ tube formation in serum at 37°C)

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of facial pain, swelling, and nasal discharge. The patient was recently hospitalized for a COVID-19 infection and treated with a prolonged course of steroids. Examination of the nasal discharge under the microscope shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mucor

Explanation:

  • Mucor species cause mucormycosis, an invasive fungal infection seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with uncontrolled diabetes or prolonged steroid use (such as post-COVID-19 patients).
  • It often presents as rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis with symptoms including facial pain, swelling, nasal discharge, and black eschar in the nasal mucosa.
  • Histopathology shows broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching, which is characteristic of Mucorales.
  • Mucor species similar characteristics to Rhizopus, including non-septate hyphae. However, it is less frequently implicated compared to Rhizopus arrhizus in cases of sinus infections. More in Covid-19 due to use of steroids.

Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus:

Absidia:

Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained):

 

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

It does not commonly present as invasive sino-orbital disease. Microscopically, Candida shows budding yeasts and pseudohyphae, rather than hyphal invasion seen in Mucor.
